Award.AwardTitle: RUI Collaborative Research: Systematics and Biogeography of Mite Harvestmen of the Australian Wet Tropics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Why do rainforest habitats support such a large diversity of animal life? One way to approach this question is to test hypotheses about the evolutionary origins of that diversity. This research project will use modern genetic tools to test the hypothesis that fragmentation of forest habitats during the Last Glacial Maximum approximately 18,000 years ago drove the speciation process in a group of tiny arachnids, the mite harvestmen, in the Wet Tropics of Queensland, Australia. In addition, the researchers will name and describe many species of this poorly known animal group that are new to science. Specimens will be deposited in the Queensland Museum and the Harvard Museum of Comparative Zoology, and will be available to professional biologists through loans from the museums.

Over the course of this project, six undergraduate students will participate in fieldwork in Queensland, and at least 20 undergraduates will be trained in lab research techniques such as scanning electron microscopy and DNA sequencing. Student learning will happen both during the summer months, when students will be supported to work full-time on independent research projects, and as part of coursework at Macalester College. In addition, the researchers will work with outreach staff at the Bell Museum of Natural History (University of Minnesota) to disseminate the results of this work to the public through talks and exhibits.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The world's biodiversity is distributed unevenly across the surface of the Earth, with some areas harboring many more species than other areas.  Understanding the causes of this general pattern is fundamental to preserving and managing the planet's species in the face of global environmental changes. Our project used the mite harvestmen that inhabit Australia's wet tropical forests to assess whether variation in the number of species occupying different forest fragments is driven by the amount of evolutionary time the fragments have been occupied (Do they act as time capsules/museums by preserving diversity?), or the rate at which species in the fragments diversify over time (Do they act a engines or pumps for the formation of new species?). Using a combination of data that quantifies the timing of species formation and reconstructions of the expansion and contraction of wet tropical forests over geological time, we found that forest fragments that were more continuously forested over time have more species and have been inhabited longer than those where the presence of forested habitat was less stable. Overall, the results support the idea that the amount of time that areas have been inhabited, rather than the rate at which species multiply, govern spatial variation in biodiversity in this ecologically important group of invertebrates.  During the course of this project, two female students pursuing their PhD degrees were trained in methodologies in evolution, ecology, and geographic-information science that are critical to managing Earth's biodiversity in the context of rapid, global environmental change.
